14. Underwater activities involving artificial breathing apparatus. This exclusion does not apply to leisure scuba diving under the supervision of a qualified diving instructor, if You hold a PADI certification (or equivalent qualification), and the maximum depth of the dive does not exceed the maximum depth limit under Your certification or thirty (30) metres, whichever is shallower.
15. Manual work of any kind unless You have informed Us when applying for the insurance and it is accepted by Us in writing.
16. Your negligence or Your failure to take due and reasonable care and precautions to safeguard and secure Your properties.
17. Taking part in expeditions or the crewing of a vessel from one country to another or engaging in active service in the armed forces of any nation.
questions: How does the policy define coverage for underwater activities involving artificial breathing apparatus, including the requirements for PADI certification, supervision by a qualified diving instructor, and maximum depth limits?
In what circumstances is manual work covered under the policy, and what are the requirements for notifying and obtaining written acceptance from the insurer?
How does the policy address claims arising from negligence or failure to take reasonable care in safeguarding and securing personal properties, and what impact does this have on claim eligibility?
What exclusions apply to participation in expeditions or crewing vessels between countries, and how does this interact with coverage for active service in the armed forces?
If a policyholder engages in leisure scuba diving without PADI certification or equivalent, or exceeds the maximum depth limit, how does the exclusion for underwater activities apply?
What documentation or proof might be required to demonstrate compliance with the manual work notification and acceptance condition for coverage eligibility?
How does the exclusion for negligence or failure to safeguard property interact with claims for lost or stolen items during travel?
Are there any exceptions or conditions under which manual work performed during travel could be covered despite the general exclusion?
How does the policy treat claims related to injuries or losses sustained during expeditions or active military service, and are there any potential exceptions?
What are the implications for coverage if a policyholder undertakes a diving activity supervised by an instructor but dives beyond their certified maximum depth or 30 metres?
How does the policy distinguish between leisure scuba diving and other underwater activities involving artificial breathing apparatus in terms of coverage and exclusions?
In cases where manual work was not disclosed at application but is discovered after a claim, how might this affect the claim outcome?
How does the exclusion for negligence or failure to take reasonable care apply to situations involving unattended property or theft during travel?
What is the policy's stance on coverage for crewing a vessel for private versus commercial purposes, and how does this relate to the exclusion for expeditions?
How might the exclusion for active service in the armed forces affect coverage for reservists or individuals called to duty during their trip?
If a policyholder holds an equivalent diving qualification to PADI, what criteria must be met for the underwater activities exclusion to not apply?
How does the policy handle claims arising from underwater activities that are not supervised by a qualified instructor but are within the certified depth limits?
What are the consequences for coverage if a policyholder fails to inform the insurer about manual work and suffers an injury related to that work during the trip?
How does the exclusion for expeditions or crewing vessels interact with other policy sections that might cover travel delays or medical emergencies during such activities?
In what ways does the policy require proof of supervision and certification for leisure scuba diving to validate coverage and avoid the underwater activities exclusion?
